node.title: Stitch Mesh
node.bodyText:
Hello MOOSE experts,
I am trying to stitch three meshes and getting the following error:
Errors:
In UnstructuredMesh::stitch_meshes:
This mesh has 7 nodes on boundary 2.
Other mesh has 7 nodes on boundary 0.
Minimum edge length on both surfaces is 1.66667e-06.
In UnstructuredMesh::stitch_meshes:
Found 7 matching nodes.

*** ERROR ***
std::bad_alloc

*** ERROR ***
std::bad_alloc

*** ERROR ***
std::bad_alloc

application called MPI_Abort(MPI_COMM_WORLD, 1) - process 2

*** ERROR ***
std::bad_alloc

application called MPI_Abort(MPI_COMM_WORLD, 1) - process 3
application called MPI_Abort(MPI_COMM_WORLD, 1) - process 0
application called MPI_Abort(MPI_COMM_WORLD, 1) - process 1

Mesh Generators:
d = 10e-6
y_copper = 10e-6
y_buffer = 11e-6
y_silicon = 25e-6

Nodes_x = 6  # 6 nodes for 10e-6 length


[Mesh]

coord_type = RZ

 [./gen1]
    type = GeneratedMeshGenerator
    dim = 2
    nx = ${Nodes_x}
    ny = 5
    xmin = 0
    xmax = ${d}
    ymin = 0
    ymax = ${y_copper}
  [../]
  [bottom_block]
    type = SubdomainIDGenerator
    input = gen1
    subdomain_id = 0
  []

  [./gen2]
    type = GeneratedMeshGenerator
    dim = 2
    nx = ${Nodes_x}
    ny = 7
    xmin = 0
    xmax = ${d}
    ymin = ${y_copper}
    ymax = ${y_buffer}
  [../]
  [middle_block]
    type = SubdomainIDGenerator
    input = gen2
    subdomain_id = 1
  []

  [./gen3]
    type = GeneratedMeshGenerator
    dim = 2
    nx = ${Nodes_x}
    ny = 7
    xmin = 0
    xmax = ${d}
    ymin = ${y_buffer}
    ymax = ${y_silicon}
  [../]
  [top_block]
    type = SubdomainIDGenerator
    input = gen3
    subdomain_id = 2
  []

  [two_blocks]
    type = StitchedMeshGenerator
    inputs = 'bottom_block middle_block top_block'
    clear_stitched_boundary_ids = true
    stitch_boundaries_pairs = 'top bottom top bottom'
    parallel_type = 'replicated' 
  []
[]

Can you please help me to figure out the solution? Thank you.
Best,
Avtar

Hello
The error message is not great but basically the stitiching failed.
The meshes are overlapping. Is this desired?
I think you actually want to adjust xmin and xmax in every generator to make them stack?
Guillaume

Hello Guillaume,
Yes, I want them to be of same radius. I am stacking them in y-direction keeping length in r-direction same.
If I do only two blocks its working. As soon as I add third, the error pops up.
Best,
Avtar
ok just use two stitcher blocks then and we ll look at it

Sorry for misunderstanding.
By two blocks, I mean if I stitched two meshes its working. As soon as I added third mesh, I am getting the above error.
I tried to add two stitched blocks, its not working as well and getting the following error:
Your MeshGenerator tree contains multiple possible generator outputs :
"two_blocks_2 and one or more of the following from an independent set: "bottom_block, gen1, two_blocks_1"

This may be due to a missing dependency or may be intentional. Please select the final MeshGenerator in
the [Mesh] block with the "final_generator" parameter or add additional dependencies to remove the ambiguity.

Avtar

You need to make sure there is one generator at the end of the tree of generators.
Right now it s not clear what the last one is, you need to make sure all the meshes end up in the same mesh.
Maybe you need to stitch the intermediate stitched mesh and the 3rd mesh together?

Resolved.
Thanks,
Avtar

node.title: Keep mesh centered without pinning nodes?
node.bodyText:
I'm trying to recreate some Abaqus results in MOOSE. To more easily measure model distortions, the mesh is kept centered by applying constraints that force the displacements of certain nodes (corner nodes for example) to sum to zero. In Abaqus you can also explicitly set the rotational degrees of freedom to zero so there is no rigid body motion.
I have written a NodalKernel for MOOSE that does the mesh centering, but some rotation can still occur. Is there a way I can prevent rotations without pinning nodes?

Hello
Could you follow the same approach and force some measure of the displacement from a rotation (maybe |disp| to avoid compensation between opposite nodes) to sum to zero?
Guillaume
Sounds reasonable but how do you measure the rotation?
Oh it s not always around the origin that you forced?
no, the meshes I'm working with are all over the place.

is the rotation always around the center of mass though?
is the axis always the same too?
Does this all depend on which nodes you chose to pin by forcing the displacement sum to 0?

I've only inspected it visually, but it does seem the rotation is about the center. Just looking at 2D models for now. Haven't played around with the constraint nodes since those are already built in to the Abaqus models I'm working with.
if you know that center you could compute a moment with the displacement for the constraint node and try to constain that.

I do know the point coordinates (which are also a nodeset), so computing the centroid is no problem.
Guess I would need to find the component of the displacement that is perpendicular to the radial vector (center to point), sum those for each point, and constrain that value?

I think to compute the moment you would also need to multiply by the radial vector length.
But both of these are heuristics so either could work?
Any luck with this heuristic or the petsc nullspace removal?

I ended up implementing the ad-hoc sum-to-zero constraints I mentioned using NodalKernels for applying forces and ScalarKernels for computing Lagrange multipliers. Multiple constraints were needed to prevent both rotation and translation. Unfortunately my abilities with petsc don't go beyond passing petsc options in the MOOSE input file, so I never tried to tackle the null space removal.
There's a capability in petsc which automatically computes and removes (near) null spaces in the context of solid mechanics. @reverendbedford recently tried that IIRC.
I suppose I should finish that PR...

There's a capability in petsc which automatically computes and removes (near) null spaces in the context of solid mechanics. @reverendbedford recently tried that IIRC.

@hugary1995 does this capability currently exist in MOOSE?

Let me back up and make sure I'm doing things right. What I'm after is for all $i$ nodes in my nodeset: $\sum_{i} disp_{x,i}=0$, $\sum_{i} disp_{y,i}=0$ and not $disp_{x,i}=0$, $disp_{y,i}=0$.
I'm using PenaltyDirichletNodalKernel with value=0.0. Is that what I want or do I need to do something different?

node.title: Negative mass/concentration problem
node.bodyText:
Dear all,
I am stuck with a numerical problem with our application. Here I want to show one simple model to ask a question.
I have a 1D model and let water flow through the 1D system by setting a constant water flow rate at one boundary. In addition, I want to have a chemical component following the water to flow through the 1D system by giving a constant concentration at the boundary with water injection. Initially, there is only water in the system.
Now the question is after computation, there is always a negative value for chemical component concentration (please see figure below), even at the first time step.
I tried to check my code and solver conditions but nothing helps me with the negative value. Could you help to give some comments regarding that? Thanks in advance. Attached are my input file and results.

Hello
You have boundary conditions on both ends for this solute right?
It doesnt seem physically to have an inlet at a concentration and an outlet at 0.
Is the solute supposed to have entirely reacted or something? I dont see a loss/reaction kernel
Guillaume

Hello
You have boundary conditions on both ends for this solute right? It doesnt seem physically to have an inlet at a concentration and an outlet at 0. Is the solute supposed to have entirely reacted or something? I dont see a loss/reaction kernel
Guillaume

Yes. I have boundary conditions on both ends for this solute.
If I only set the inlet at a concentration and do not set an outlet, I still got similar results with some negative concentrations (shown in the attached picture).
Only the advection of concentration is considered in this process. There are no loss/reaction kernels.

What is the advection velocity here?
The solute concentration is essentially 0 here. So the advection and the diffusion are not propagating the solute
while some numbers are negative, they are mostly 0

What is the advection velocity here? The solute concentration is essentially 0 here. So the advection and the diffusion are not propagating the solute

The advection velocity value is 3.5e-6 m/s, which is the artificial darcy velocity. In the first time step (t= 0.1 s), some solute values are negative and close to 0 but the minimum value is -0.15. Also, as time goes on （i.e., 363.4s）, the minimum solute concentration can be minus several hundred (-545. 818, shown in the attached pictures).

ok this latest screenshot does show this more clearly.
Is this with the two boundary conditions on both ends? As I was mentioning earlier, this seems unphysical.
Or with the single boundary condition on one end?

node.title: Solution not converging by number of iteration as expected
node.bodyText:
Hello,
I am trying two solve a simple poison equation with two subdomains using MultiApp. The idea is to use RobinBC at the interface. Now, the solution is expected to have a different convergence rate as the scalar value (alpha) changes. It should converge to the same solution though with a different number of iterations. I am getting that my solution converges in two iterations for all values of alpha. This is weird. Please what could I do to achieve a different convergence rate as the alpha changes, and for it to converge to the same true solution at every single time?
More specifically, the idea is to have the solutions transferred to and from each subdomain at every step of the iteration until convergence. Currently, I think the right subdomain solves and send the result to the left. Then the left sub uses those values in its calculation and output the result. That's the two iterations. How can I make the results to be sent back and forth until convergence?
Thank you!
-----------------------------
Right Subdomain
-------------------------------
[Mesh]
  type = GeneratedMesh
  dim = 1
  nx = 1
  xmin = 1
  xmax = 2

[]

[Variables]
  [v]
    order = FIRST
    family = LAGRANGE
  []
[]

[AuxVariables]
  [flux_v]
    order = CONSTANT
    family = MONOMIAL
  []
[]

[Kernels]
  [diffusion]
    type = MatDiffusion
    variable = v
    diffusivity = 1
  []
[]

[AuxKernels]
  [fluxKernel]
    type = DiffusionFluxAux
    diffusivity = 1
    variable = flux_v
    diffusion_variable = v
    component = x
  []
[]

[BCs]
  [interface_leftBC] 
    type = VacuumBC
    variable = v
    boundary = 'left'
    alpha = 2
  []
  
  [rightBC] 
    type = NeumannBC
    variable = v
    boundary = 'right'
    value = 3
  []
[]

[Functions]
  [BC_vleft_Neumann]
    type = ParsedFunction
    value = '-a'
    vars = 'a'
    vals = 'u_flux_right'
  []
[]

[Postprocessors]
  [left_vflux]
    type = PointValue
    variable = 'flux_v'
    point = '1 0 0'
   []
  [left_vval]
    type = PointValue
    variable = 'v'
    point = '1 0 0'
   []
  [uval_right]
    type = Receiver
  []
  [u_flux_right]
    type = Receiver
  []
  
  [no_picard_its]
    type = NumFixedPointIterations
    execute_on = 'initial timestep_end'
  []

[]

[Executioner]
  type = Steady
  solve_type = 'PJFNK'
  
  #type = Transient
  #num_steps = 10
  #dt = 1

  fixed_point_max_its = 50
  nl_abs_tol = 1e-10
  fixed_point_rel_tol = 1e-16
  fixed_point_abs_tol = 1e-10

  petsc_options_iname = '-pc_type -pc_hypre_type'
  petsc_options_value = 'hypre boomeramg'
[]

[Outputs]
  exodus = true
  csv = true
  console = true
[]

[VectorPostprocessors]
  [point_sample]
    type = PointValueSampler
    variable = 'v flux_v'
    points = '1 0 0'
    sort_by = x
  []
[]

-----------------------------
Left Subdomain
---------------------------

[Mesh]
  type = GeneratedMesh
  dim = 1
  nx = 1
  xmin = 0
  xmax = 1

[]

[Variables]
  [u]
    order = FIRST
    family = LAGRANGE
  []
[]

[AuxVariables]
  [flux_u]
    order = CONSTANT
    family = MONOMIAL
  []
[]

[Kernels]
  [diffusion]
    type = MatDiffusion
    variable = u
    diffusivity = 1
  []
[]

[AuxKernels]
  [fluxKernel]
    type = DiffusionFluxAux
    diffusivity = 1
    variable = flux_u
    diffusion_variable = u
    component = x
  []
[]

[BCs]
  [leftBC] 
    type = DirichletBC
    variable = u
    boundary = 'left'
    value = 0
  []

  [interfaceBC_right] 
    type = FunctionNeumannBC
    variable = u
    boundary = 'right'
    function = interface_flux_right
  []

 
[]

[Functions]

   type = ParsedFunction

   vars = 'a'
   vals = 'v_flux_left'
  []

  [interface_right]
   type = ParsedFunction

  []
  
[]

[Postprocessors]
  [right_uflux]
    type = PointValue

  [right_uval]

   []

  []

    type = Receiver
  []
  
  [picard_its]

  []
[]


[Executioner]

  #type = Transient

[]

[Outputs]

[MultiApps]

  []

[Transfers]

    to_postprocessor = u_flux_right
  []
  [uval_t]
    type = MultiAppPostprocessorTransfer

    to_postprocessor = uval_right
  []

    to_postprocessor = vval_left
  [] 
[]

---------------------------------
When solved without subdomain
------------------------------------
[Mesh]
  type = GeneratedMesh
  dim = 1
  nx = 1
  xmin = 0
  xmax = 2

[]

[Variables]
  [v]
    order = FIRST
    family = LAGRANGE
  []
[]

[AuxVariables]
  [flux_v]
    order = CONSTANT
    family = MONOMIAL
  []
[]

[Kernels]
  [diffusion]
    type = MatDiffusion
    variable = v
    diffusivity = 1
  []
[]

[AuxKernels]
  [fluxKernel]
    type = DiffusionFluxAux
    diffusivity = 1
    variable = flux_v
    diffusion_variable = v
    component = x
  []
[]

[BCs]
   [leftBC] 
    type = DirichletBC
    variable = v
    boundary = 'left'
    value = 0
  []

  [rightBC] 
    type = NeumannBC
    variable = v
    boundary = 'right'
    value = 3
  []
[]


[Executioner]
  type = Steady
  solve_type = 'PJFNK'
[]

[Outputs]
  exodus = true
  csv = true
  console = true
[]

[Postprocessors]
  [picard_its]
    type = NumFixedPointIterations
    execute_on = 'initial timestep_end'
  [../]
[]


[VectorPostprocessors]
  [point_sample]
    type = PointValueSampler
    variable = 'v flux_v'
    points = '1 0 0'
    sort_by = x
  []
[]

Hello
The numerical scheme is not exactly the same between those two cases.
In the fully coupled, single input case, you are using PJFNK to solve the entire problem.
In the tightly coupled, two inputs case, you are using PJFNK to solve each problem, but you are using a simple fixed point iteration scheme for the coupled problem.
Guillaume

Thanks for your reply.

So, could you suggest a better option than the Numerical scheme I chose?


Thanks!
…

 Hello

 The numerical scheme is not exactly the same between those two cases.

 In the fully coupled, single input case, you are using PJFNK to solve the
 entire problem.
 In the tightly coupled, two inputs case, you are using PJFNK to solve each
 problem, but you are using a simple fixed point iteration scheme for the
 coupled problem.

 Guillaume

Is there a reason you do not want to solve both problems at the same time in the same input?
Have you tried relaxation of the picard iteration? (setting a fixed point relaxation factor and the variable to relax)

The idea is to use MultiApp, using different input.

I haven't tried the relaxation yet. I'll try that.

This is unlikely to converge if Picard fixed point iterations dont converge

Thanks, I'll check it out.

I got it working.
I conceptualized the boundary conditions better and reformulated it.
Awesome. Please feel free to explain more so others can learn from your experiences.

Okay. I think it is problem specific
By reformulating the BC, this is what I did:

So, I implemented the first equation in my left subdomain and the second in the right subdomain, paying attention to the signs coming from the fluxes from the two subdomains. The left side of the equations is implemented as the robin/vacuum BC, while the right sides are from the transferred values. The idea is that as the lambda and the alpha change, the solution should converge at different rates to achieve the same result. Note that the lambda and the alpha are the iteration parameters.

node.title: Understanding which factors influence memory usage?
node.bodyText:
Hi all,
I have recently been encountering the following error when trying to run an fsi simulation:
Linear solve did not converge due to DIVERGED_PC_FAILED iterations 0
PC failed due to FACTOR_OUTMEMORY
Nonlinear solve did not converge due to DIVERGED_LINE_SEARCH
Generally speaking, I am aware that this is probably caused by using an lu preconditioner, which is very memory intensive.
However, so far, no alternatives which converge have been found (I am planning on making another post about this soon, but am happy to discuss here if relevant).
Through observation of when this error appears, it is clear that a number of other parameters have a significant effect on the memory usage.
Some of these are perfectly intuitive such as mesh size and number of variables. However, others, such as time step size, and number of cores used are less obvious.
I would like to understand how the above factors affect memory usage, as well as any others which may be significant (For instance, I am guessing number of kernels has an effect?).
Hopefully this will help improve things whilst the search for a more appropriate preconditioner continues!
Thanks!

Hello
LU tends to report out of memory simply when it fails, not only when it s truly out of memory.
You should try to investigate whether the system is well conditioned, see this comment
#22425 (reply in thread)
If all is well, to improve conditioning the next step is likely to try a field split
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/preconditioners/FieldSplitPreconditioner.html
Guillaume

Thanks for the suggestions - I have a couple of questions about each of these:
To see the singular value composition as per your comment in the linked thread, am I right in thinking I should replace my current petsc options with the following in the executioner block:
petsc_options = '-pc_svd_monitor'
petsc_options_iname = '-pc_type'
petsc_options_value = 'svd'
With these options alone, the simulation just seems to sit there not attempting the first timestep, so I wonder if I need to add some other options?
EDIT: I have realised that svd is only useful for small problems - I will try to create a version with fewer dofs to investigate this.
When using field split, would you typically use the same preconditioner (in this case for instance, lu), or is the idea that splitting the variables could allow less 'strong' pc's such as ilu to work for each subsolver?
No I would not use LU everywhere, some physics are likely to be easy enough to solve that you dont need a direct solver

node.title: Should we remove local, nonsparse AD indexing?
node.bodyText: There are documented cases where the local indexing, nonsparse container is faster than our default global indexing, sparse container (see #17674). However, the local indexing container is essentially unusable for MOOSE FV (at least as it is currently implemented) and generally is untenable as the element coupling stencil increases; for standard DG it is fine, but for any more element neighbor layers than 1, things are tough. Additionally the global indexing container is much easier to use as a developer.
Will removing this capability prevent us from using AD for other purposes? For instance, our optimization work is looking into using AD to compute residual derivatives w.r.t. parameter values.
No. You would likely want to use the sparse (default) container for that

I would be very surprised if forward AD (regardless of container type) works well for parameter partials... say you have one objective function and millions of quadrature points each having a parameter.
Yeah, the application is not that. It would be a few model parameters or a reduced resolution parameter mesh.

We're getting off-topic but in the conversations I've heard about this, you want to get an idea about how a parameter may effect something like a postprocessor value. Forward AD could pretty easily calculate the explicit dependence of the postprocessor on a parameter, but if the postprocessor is a function of the nonlinear degrees of freedom (or even the aux system dofs) and the parameter influences the nonlinear solution (say its viscosity in a navier-stokes simulation), how do you capture the implicit dependence of the postprocessor on the parameter through the system dofs? @grmnptr I know we've touched on this stuff briefly

I think it's a little simpler than what you are describing @lindsayad . I just need the derivative of the residual w.r.t. to a parameter. So if you had N dofs and P parameters, the derivative would be a matrix N-by-P.

node.title: Picard iteration divergence problem during MultiApps coupling
node.bodyText:
Hi all,
I was running a MultiApps problem,  main app is a heat conduction problem, and sub app is a simple lumped parameter problem. The calculation process is that main app uses the initial temperature boundary conditions to calculate steady-state heat conduction, after that, the integrate heat flux is postprocessed at the boundary and then transfer to the sub app to calculate and update the boundary temperature and continue the iteration.
I set Picard iteration in the [Executioner] block, use the default fixed_point_rel_tol, and set fixed_point_min_its to 2. The calculation converge in the second picard iteration, and the results look reasonable; However, when I set fixed_point_min_its to larger (10), it still converges after the tenth picard iteration, but the result is different and extremely unreasonable.
So I have two questions:

Seems Picard iteration is not converged from the calculation results, then why it showed solve converged?
What parameters can be adjusted to improve the convergence of iteration? I've tried to set relaxation_factor to <1, and also refine the mesh or reduce the tolerance to enhanced convergence, but still no improvement.

Any guidance is greatly appreciated!

Hello
Can you please attach the logs for these two runs?
One thing to note is that the criterion for convergence of these multiapps coupling is the residual in the main app. So if the subapp does not influence the main app much (can happen also if you are missing a transfer from the subapp to the main app), you can have a converged fixed point iteration between the apps, yet the subapp result is not converged.
Relaxation factor is the only lever pretty much here. Everything else only deals with how converged the result should be.
Other fixed point iteration algorithms are more brittle than Picard as well
Guillaume

Thanks for your reply Guillaume.
I attached the log files and main app input here.
log_2_iterations.txt
log_10_iterations.txt
input.txt
I originally thought fixed point iteration is that the two fields exchange data in one Picard iteration step and converge relative to the previous step, so I thought that the convergence criterion of fixed point iteration was the field value difference between two iteration steps. Did I misunderstand?

I should double check, but it should not be that.
We have a very valid way of checking if something is converged, by computing the residual. We dont need to rely on the difference between two iterations.
Two things:
 0 Picard |R| = 5.290898e+04
 1 Picard |R| = 2.343748e-07
 2 Picard |R| = 5.052297e-12
 3 Picard |R| = 4.752913e-04
 4 Picard |R| = 2.395892e-11
 5 Picard |R| = 3.797361e-07
 6 Picard |R| = 2.392503e-11
 7 Picard |R| = 2.137410e-09
 8 Picard |R| = 2.585106e-11
 9 Picard |R| = 4.846381e-09
10 Picard |R| = 3.554305e-11

the main app residual is jumping around between odd and even fixed point iterations/.
Similarly:
fixed point 5
HP80: Time Step 1, time = 1, dt = 1
HP80:  0 Nonlinear |R| = 1.128290e-06
HP80:  1 Nonlinear |R| = 2.371580e-10
HP80:  Solve Converged!

fixed point 6
HP80: Time Step 1, time = 1, dt = 1
HP80:  0 Nonlinear |R| = 1.832242e-01
HP80:  1 Nonlinear |R| = 4.521310e-05
HP80:  2 Nonlinear |R| = 1.649082e-08
HP80:  3 Nonlinear |R| = 3.225161e-12
HP80:  Solve Converged!

the residual of the subapps are also jumping around between fixed point iterations. in fact it seems to grow every other iteration.
This is symptomatic of either instability or a problem with the timing of execution of the transfers pipeline.
Right now I see this:
  [boundary_temp_post2]
    type = ScalarVariable
    variable = boundary_temp2
    execute_on = TIMESTEP_BEGIN
  []

this will lag the postprocessor by one iteration. It might be the issue. Execute this more often by using the default or adding more execute_on

As you are probably already aware of, Picard isn't necessarily convergent: https://arxiv.org/pdf/1410.1390.pdf
The simplest way to tell if Picard is convergent is by looking at each sub-problem and check

if the sequence of Picard iterates are bounded
if the sub-problem is convex

If both are true, then Picard should converge, though the convergence interval may vary.
Thanks for your guidance @hugary1995 , I actually suspect that my coupling problem itself is divergent... I will read the paper of this link and try to find more clues.

@GiudGiud I tried these things, and I've set a very small relaxation factor, but still no improvement.
I don't know yet how to mathematically analyze the convergence of this coupling problem, while I briefly analyzed from the physical aspect.
The coupling parameters are the heat flux and boundary temperature, because the thermal conductivity of the problem is large and the geometry is small, small temperature differences can lead to large heat flux differences, which in turn make larger temperature differences, results to divergence.
So I changed the thermal conductivity directly to 1% of what it was before, and picard converge well without underrelaxation.
So I can probably infer that the problem itself doesn't converge. Do you have any suggestions?

But did you specify which variables to relax?
Is the system itself physically unstable?

Yes by declaring the transformed_variables parameter = temp. Can be seen that setting a smaller relaxation factor will cause the picard to have a tendency of convergence at the first few iterations, but still will diverge at specific iteration step, like
 0 Picard |R| = 1.234543e+05
 1 Picard |R| = 1.641611e-09
 2 Picard |R| = 1.539429e+04
 3 Picard |R| = 1.154572e+04
 4 Picard |R| = 8.735435e+03
 5 Picard |R| = 6.575765e+03
 6 Picard |R| = 4.931576e+03
 7 Picard |R| = 3.692373e+03
 8 Picard |R| = 2.752174e+03
 9 Picard |R| = 2.109329e+03
10 Picard |R| = 1.582342e+03
11 Picard |R| = 1.610063e+03
12 Picard |R| = 2.204031e+03
13 Picard |R| = 2.017019e+03
14 Picard |R| = 7.424021e+03
15 Picard |R| = 1.106489e+03
16 Picard |R| = 2.244228e+04
17 Picard |R| = 1.633168e+04
18 Picard |R| = 5.725446e+04
19 Picard |R| = 9.156200e+04
20 Picard |R| = 1.372499e+05
21 Picard |R| = 6.423847e+05

A larger relaxation factor leads to faster divergence, which implies to some extent, the relaxation factor is effective. But I guess this problem is physically unstable actually.

You should try to use the conservative transfer parameters. This will reduce the impact of numerical errors during transfers
if the problem is physically unstable, you should try to add a constraint when solving it. Maybe force the integral of a quantity to be constant between each solve

node.title: How to output '_flow_direction' in the file 'CrystalPlasticityStressUpdateBase.C' to exodus file
node.bodyText:
Hello All
I want to output '_flow_direction' in the file 'CrystalPlasticityStressUpdateBase.C' to exodus file. Since it has been defined in the file 'CrystalPlasticityStressUpdateBase.C' like:
_flow_direction(declareProperty<std::vector<RankTwoTensor>>(_base_name + "flow_direction")),
So I directly add a new variable in .inp file trying to output it.

[SchmidTensor_xx]
type = RankTwoAux
variable = SchmidTensor_xx
rank_two_tensor = flow_direction
index_j = 0
index_i = 0
execute_on = timestep_end
[../]

But when I run codes, it displays an error 'Material has no property named: flow_direction'. How do I output '_flow_direction'
Here is my inp file:https://github.com/pshen20127/IN625.git
Thanks
Pengfei

Hello
The name of this property is not just flow_direction.
It's _base_name + "flow_direction"
so you need to add this base name.
If you dont know it you can use the [Debug] option to show all material properties created
Guillaume

There's not a base_name specified in the input file, so using rank_two_tensor = flow_direction ought to work
@pshen20127 I see you are using your own class in the input file. I'll see if I can replicate this error with the original CrystalPlasticityKalidindiUpdate class. If not, we'll probably need to see your crystal plasticity class in order to help further

The issue here is that each slip system (in your case there are 12) has it's own Schmid tensor, so the material property flow_direction is a vector of Rank-2 tensors:
_flow_direction(declareProperty<std::vector<RankTwoTensor>>(_base_name + "flow_direction")),

As such, the usual RankTwoAux that we use for outputting tensors like the plastic deformation gradient won't work here. Same thing for the MaterialStdVectorAux that we use to output the slip system resistance and slip increments.
@GiudGiud do we have an auxkernel that can output a specific tensor component from a tensor within a vector of tensors?
no I dont think we have that one
It would not be hard to make at all

@sapitts @GiudGiud Thanks for your reply. Are all auxkernels stored in the directorties '/moose/modules/tensor_mechanics/src/auxkernels' and '/moose/framework/src/auxkernels' ? I have checked these 2 folders and don't find any works. Will you write an auxkernel that can output this type of variables? Or could you suggest other ways that can output this variable?

node.title: Value storage problem

node.bodyText:
If you are truly out of bounds, you could be printing part of the next tensor.
based on the other thread, you are using a vector of tensor material property
In general you should not print out of bounds
Get it, thank you.

node.title: setting input file subblocks as active/inactive
node.bodyText:
I have an input file with this format:
[BCs]
  active = ''
  [fixed_x]
    type = DirichletBC
    ....
  []
  [InclinedNoDisplacementBC]
    [inclined]
      boundary = inclined_nodes
      ...
    []
  []
[]

I want to switch on my BCs from the command line, but it doesn't seem I can set the inclined BC as active using the top-level parameters? I've tried appending both BCs/active="fixed_x InclinedNoDisplacementBC/inclined" and BCs/active="fixed_x" BCs/InclinedNoDisplacementBC/active="inclined" to the command line but neither seem to work.

Hello
InclineNoDisplacementBC is an action within the BCs block. I m afraid it won't work the same way as two regular BCs and you pick which is active.
But, if this particular action supports it, you should be able to do:
[BCs]
  inactive / active = 'fixed_x InclinedNoDisplacementBC'
  [fixed_x]
    type = DirichletBC
    ....
  []
  [InclinedNoDisplacementBC]
    ~~inactive/active = 'inclined'~~
    [inclined]
      boundary = inclined_nodes
      ...
    []
  []
[]

but you d have to look at it closely to know if that action supports active/inactive
It looks like I can turn the whole action on (or off) with BCs/active=InclinedNoDisplacementBC, which works for now.
ok then no issue?
or do you need to be able to specify within this nested action which BCs should be active?
Yeah right now I either have inclined BCs or I don't, so turning them all off is ok.

or do you need to be able to specify within this nested action which BCs should be active?

Maybe someday!
